title: kim jong un sister kim yo jong
story: With her brother reported to be ill, she has been tipped to take over the country should the Supreme Leader die.Kim, , was born in September , the daughter of North Korean dictator Kim Jong-il.She is said to have had a close relationship with brother Kim Jong-un from an early age.Both studied together in Switzerland between  and  with each depending on the other for company and support during those isolated years.It is believed she went on to further her education at the Kim Il-sung Military University and then computer science at the Kim Il-sung university.Kim is married to Choe Song, the son of top North Korean military official and politician Choe Ryong-hae, and has at least one child born in May .During the Winter Olympics, it was reported she was pregnant with her second child.She was very rarely seen in public until , when she was photographed at a party conference, but became prominent in the lead up to her fathers death in .She is thought to have helped arrange her brothers succession to Supreme Leader.Her first job title given in a state news address was a senior official of the ruling Workers Party Central Committee.In , In November , Yo-jong was named First Deputy Director of the Workers Partys Propaganda and Agitation Department.She accompanied her brother during elections the same year, signalling her increasing importance in the hermit kingdom.She was made a member of the politburo, the partys most senior ruling committee, in , giving her even greater power including over state security.In , she represented North Korea and her brother at the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.Later that year, she attended the Singapore summit on June  between Donald Trump and the North Korean leader.The dictators sister was spotted at the signing between the two leaders stepping up to swap a pen which had been provided to sign the agreement.But she was then demoted in , after she was held responsible for the failure of the Hanoi Summit, which saw Donald Trump scrap denuclearisation talks.At the  North Korean parliamentary elections, Kim Yo-jong was elected to the Supreme Peoples Assembly as a representative for Killimgil.In early April , she was reinstated to the party’s powerful politburo according to the state Korean Central News Agency.She has had a remarkableto favour after falling out of grace with her brother following her removal from the role in  and ordered to keep a low profile.She is now thought to be the mastermind behind Kim’s public image, both at home and abroad and is believed to have the full confidence of her brother Kim who is said to have had his own uncle executed for treason.Last month Kims sister made her first public statement, condemning South Korea as a “frightened dog barking” after Seoul protested about the North’s recent live-fire military exercise.She has also publicly praised US President Donald Trump for sending Kim Jong-un a letter in which he said he hoped to maintain good bilateral relations and offered help in dealing with the coronavirus pandemic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsFund free TV licences for over-s, Labour Shadow Minister tells governmentJo Stevens, the new Shadow Culture Secretary, urged ministers to honour the Conservatives  election pledge to maintain the benefitShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  APR NewsJo Stevens writes exclusively for the Mirror " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCampaigners battling to save free TV licences were handed a fresh boost tonight as Labouraposs new Shadow Culture Secretary threw her weight behind the fight. In her first major intervention since being appointed to party leader Keir Starmeraposs top team, Jo Stevens called for the Government to honour a  manesto pledge to fund the vital leline for over-s.Writing exclusively for the Mirror, she said: “ Labour are pushing for the licence fee to be protected indefinitely.“The Government should do the right thing – step in and guarantee free licences for over-s for good.” Ms Stevens, who previously sat on the Commons Culture Select Committee, became Labouraposs third Shadow Culture Secretary in six months when she was handed the role.She called on Boris Johnson to take back control of funding the £.-a-year TV licence for millions of OAPs who face being stripped of the benefit on August . The Conservatives pledged at the  election to protect free licences for the rest of that Parliament, which was due to run until . But the BBC had already been handed responsibility for funding the leline from June , under a deal stitched up in . Cost-saving restrictions meant . million OAPs who do not receive Pension Credit would have to pay from August  – though corporation chiefs and the Government announced curbs would be delayed for two months so the elderly did not face extra turmoil during the Covid- crisis. The Mirror is campaigning to permanently save the benefit, with more than , readers backing the fight by completing coupons in the paper. Age UK charity director Caroline Abrahams said: “We are really pleased that the first act of new Shadow Culture Secretary Jo Stevens is to support the important cause of keeping TV licences free for our over-s.  “The BBC Board’s decision to delay rollout of their planned scheme until August was very welcome but this needs to be extended to the end of  – and sooner rather than later. “This would put older people’s minds at rest and makes good sense from a practical perspective too. “Older people have more than enough to worry about at the moment without having to get to grips with a new approach to TV licences and finding the cash to pay another big annual bill many can ill-afford.” Welcoming Ms Stevensapos intervention, head of the Bectu broadcasting union Philippa Childs said: “During the Covid- crisis the BBC has more than proved its value to the nation and has fulfilled its public service duty to inform, educate and entertain to an exemplary standard. “It has been a leline to the over-s who, due to increased vulnerability, have had to undergo strict isolation to protect themselves from the virus and will likely have to still do so for the foreseeable future.  “For many, the voice of the BBC will be the only one they hear for days on end. “The Government must accept that the BBC has played its part in supporting the over-s by continuing to fund free licences during the lockdown at a cost of around £million a month. “It’s now time for the Government to commit to taking back the responsibility and the cost of funding this welfare benefit that is crucial to so many over-s on our society.” Dennis Reed, director of the Silver Voices campaign group, said: “It is fantastic news that the new Shadow Secretary is supporting the free TV licence campaign as her first act in office.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Government has ordered  million tests which can showa person has already had coronavirus.It is widely believed that contracting the virus creates immunity against future infection.It is hoped the new antibody tests will be a game changer in the UKaposs battle against Covid-, and could allow people to get back to work or socialisingthey are found to have protection from infection. The tests come following a breakthrough by scientists at the University of Oxford, who are working for the Government-backed Rapid Testing Consortium and believe the test is % effective, Mail Online reports. However, the World Health Organisation warned only yesterday that there is no evidence people who develop antibodies after recovering from Covid- are immune to a second infection, casting doubts over a lockdown exit strategy which relies on the tests. The pinprick tests are expected to cost £ and could be rolled out as soon as June. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here They work by taking a small sample of blood for analysis and can provide results in as soon as  minutes. Similarly to a pregnancy test,two lines appear, users will know they have antibodies which may be able to help to fight off the killer bug. If one line appears, it means a person either does not have antibodies produced in response to coronavirus or that the test has not worked. Speaking to Mail Online, a Government source said: This could be the game changer – a breakthrough moment to help us turn the tide on the virus. The lateral flow test has been designed by analysing the blood of patients who have been infected with Covid- but have displayed few or no symptoms. The Rapid Testing Consortium believes it could deliver up to  million tests a week by the summer, meaning a total of  million by next year. Its leader, Jonathan Allis, said: We are close to picking up % of all cases where people have antibodies. Now it is just a question of scaling up the manufacturing process. Health Minister Lord Bethell said: This is a great story of how our manufacturers are stepping up to the challenge of Covid, and I am hopeful that their product will make an impact in our battle against this terrible disease.  It is understood that key workers would be first in line to be eligible for the new tests. However, WHO has warned governments against issuing immunity passports or risk-free certicates to people who have survived Covid- as their accuracy cannot be guaranteed. The UN body says the practice could actually increase the risks of continued spread, as people who have recovered may ignore advice about taking standard precautions against the virus. A spokesman said: Some governments have suggested that the detection of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-, the virus that causes COVID-, could serve as the basis for an aposimmunity passportapos or aposrisk-free certicateapos that would enable iniduals to travel or toto work assuming that they are protected against re-infection. There is currently no evidence that people who have recovered from COVID- and have antibodies are protected from a second infection. The WHO said they are continuing to review the evidence on antibody responses to the coronavirus - adding that most studies show that people who have recovered from the infection have antibodies

story: NewsSchools looking the same as before lockdown is inconceivable, Dominic Raab warnsMinisters are under mounting pressure to set out how they will end the lockdown – and why it took so long to imposeShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsDominic Raab - seen here socially distancing - said social distancing would define le for sometime to come " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Sending children back to school as before the lockdown is “inconceivable”, Dominic Raab has admitted.The First Secretary said he wouldnapost be drawn on the details of any scheme but said they would likely replicate some of the social distancing in place at schools currently, which are still being attended by the children of key workers and the most vulnerable. He told Andrew Marr: I think itaposs inconceivable they would come back without further measures Ministers are under mounting pressure to set out how they will end the lockdown – and why it took so long to impose. Mr Raab told the BBC it was “very dficult” to see how local sports clubs could play this summer while obeying social distancing rules. But he believed it might be easier for professional clubs which could use testing regimes.Mr Raab, who has been standing in for Prime Minister Boris Johnson while he recovers from the disease, said the Government would proceed cautiously in order to avoid a second peak in the outbreak."Follow the latest coronavirus updates with our liveblog here We are at a delicate and dangerous stage, he told Sky Newsaposs Sophy Ridge on Sunday programme. We need to make sure that the next steps are sure-footed, which is why we are proceeding very cautiously and we are sticking to the scientic advice with the social-distancing measures at this time, whilst doing all the homework to make sure that we are prepared in due course for the next phase.Mr Raab brushed off a call from Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer for the Government to set out an exit strategy explaining how the lockdown could eventually be lted.Until we can be confident, based on the scientic advice, that we are making sure-footed steps going forward that protect le, but also preserve our way of le, frankly it is not responsible to start speculating about the inidual measures, he said.  Shadow Health Minister Dr Rosena Allin-Khan has questioned how many families would be grieving the loss of loved oneslockdown had been enforced sooner. “It would have been impossible to save all of the lives that weaposve lost, but we did enter into lockdown too late, she told Sky News. We did not deliver PPE to the front line when it was needed, we did not follow global advice on self-isolation and we havenapost rolled out mass testing and contact tracing. So when I find myself in the unenviable position of not being able to hug someone as they cry after theyaposve said their last goodbye it makes me think how many of these grieving families could not have had to be in this position ”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn their own words, L-J and Emily Keston talk about the highs and lows of founding an inspirational London stage school... My sister and I have loved everything about theatre for as long as we can remember. We were around three when we pointed at the TV and said, ‘We want to be in there!’ Both sets of grandparents had danced, and our mother was an actress. Our dad also did all sorts of dferent sketches, so we were immersed in performing from a young age. We were able to attend a local dance school in Yorkshire and from there we worked on ious ITV dramas. Emily was in Annie on tour when she was six, and we worked on Chitty Chitty Bang Bang together. Mum would take us on the train to London, but in terms of stage schools, there wasn’t anything outside of London for us. Even when my sister and I played the Dolly sisters in Mr Selfridge as teenagers – our last acting job – we went back and forth all the time from Yorkshire to London. We both ended up going to uni, but decided to run a drama workshop for kids during the summer holidays while back home with mum. We put a call out for children aged -, sayingthey wanted the opportunity to work with people in the industry they could come along, and we got an overwhelming response.  It was a one-off workshop that covered all theatre skills and both us and the kids loved it. That got us thinking. There were stage schools that had opened up north, but we wanted to do something unique, inclusive and affordable. We decided to try and get our idea, Stagebox, started once we’d finished university. We literally put our own money into a small studio. It was important to us that we were self-starters. Our dad, who passed away last year, was a businessman, and he taught us to have a strong work ethic, so we were inspired to do it all ourselves. We wanted to run short, intensive courses and to create the industry experience that we knew kids got in London. Entry into Stagebox is by audition-only as opposed to paid-for enrolment. It’s what sets us apart. That’s really just to assess their love for it. We saw , children last year, and we have  places per ision, so it’s competitive.  This year we have some exciting celebrity guests, but at first we had local theatre show directors to help us out. We’re looking for potential. Some children have never done a class in their le, but they may have natural star quality. I can spot it by the way some kids act in the queue. It’s just a sparkle that lights up a room. The audition day mirrors our curriculum. If they’re offered a place, the four weeks is a mixture of musical theatre, television and film training, with some video shoots and audition preparation weeks. A lot of people associate child stars with pushy parents, but this isn’t the case. Both the parents and children need to be resilient, and as the industry can seem quite closed, we’re conscious to make it all feel friendly and relaxed. Our experience of being child actors obviously helps us. We definitely had nerves at auditions when we were growing up, but it’s the people in the room who put you at ease.  We always say to the kids to be their best, because their best is good enough for us. They will probably remember their first audition for the rest of their lives, so we have to make it positive. For many, it has been. We’re so proud of our success stories and love seeing our kids do well. When we met Matthew Illesley, now , he had come along from Gloucester with his siblings, who were actually the ones auditioning. But we saw him in the queue and said he had that natural star quality. Two years later he landed Rocket Man, where he played a young Elton John. One of our girls, Isobel Khan, gave us such a proud moment with her role as Annie in the West End. She came to Stagebox with no previous experience, very young, and she had an amazing voice, but again she took many years to achieve what she did. She ended up going to Toronto on tour with the show, and was the first mixed race Annie. To have ersity on stage is so important. At one point we had all three Annies in the West End, sharing the leading role at the same time.  One of our students, Millie Kiss, has a story that’s without doubt the saddest moment for Stagebox. She lost her mum in the Manchester bomb attacks. We all knew and loved Michelle, and I think she would be so proud of what Millie has achieved, and her resilience. She went to France, out of that tragedy, and she’s now shooting a feature film, and she’s away, independent and hard-working. That is what makes her a true star, she hasn’t let what happened define her. We’re so passionate about children from all backgrounds being able to access training and opportunities. We’re actually just about to launch a government-funded scheme to help with this. To add to that, we do a monthly membership plan, which meanspeople can’t afford it, we break down the costs. It depends on the location, but we have an extensive scheme of scholarships and bursaries. We fund them ourselves from our savings, so where children are on scholarships from low-income backgrounds, we also pay for their travel, their lunch and unorm and other things, to make sure everyone is treated the same.  The children are all professionally chaperoned to auditions, and sometimes the parents are allowed to go with them when they film. They’re looked after very well by the production teams. In the last five years, we’ve been doing such extensive casting processes that we were approached to cast children ourselves, which is where our second company, Keston  Keston, was formed.

Kenneth, who lost his right leg above the knee in fighting after D-Day, had struggled to his local park on crutches to join the national party. Worried about his future prospects, he “wasn’t thinking of meeting anyone, certainly not my future we”. But Kenneth, now , and Barbara, , are still together after that chance meeting on May , . Ken, who served in the Hampshire Regiment, said: “I was thinking aboutI would get my job back and how le would be as an amputee, it was all very uncertain. “I wasn’t thinking about finding a girlfriend, but it is amazing we met in that crowd and are together  years later.” Barbara, who was  at the time, added: “I remember there was music and dancing and he was on his own. No one was talking to him so I smiled and he gave a half-smile back.  “He was very quiet – he didn’t mention his injury at all, and has never really spoken about the war. “He was very worried about his job as he was an only child and had to look after his mother.”They wed  months later at their local church in ­Trowbridge, Wilts, and still live in the town with son Malcolm. Despite being just  when he suffered his injury, Kenneth says he felt “very lucky as there were lots of lads who didn’t make it back”. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman who became one of the first humans in Europe to receive a potential coronavirus vaccine says she is doing fine despite a rumour claiming she had died. University of Oxford microbiologist Dr Elisa Granato was one of two people to be injected on Thursday as human trials got underway just three months after studies began. More than  people have been recruited for the trial which would break recordsclaims it could deliver a marketable by September are met. Dr Granato told the BBC after being injected on her nd birthday: Iaposm a scientist, so I wanted to try to support the scientic process wherever I can. Since I don’t study viruses, I felt a bit useless these days, so I felt like this is a very easy way for me to support the cause. Cancer researcher Edward OaposNeill was also injected on Thursday. But rumours began circulating earlier today that efforts had been hit by a tragic set back. An online article, soon debunked as fake news, claimed the zoology expert had died hours after having the injection after experiencing complications. It ly claimed she had pre-existing medical conditions that had not been disclosed to doctors carrying out the tests and that four others were battling complications.  The spread of the article forced Dr Granato to take to Twitter to inform her , followers she was very much alive. She said: Nothing like waking up to a fake article on your death... Iaposm doing fine everyone. Please donapost share the article in question, we donapost want to give them attention   clicks. Have a cute cat instead!has approached Dr Granato for a comment.  A spokesperson for the Department of Heath and Social Care later tweeted: News circulating on social media that the first volunteer in a UK  coronavirus vaccine trial has died is completely untrue. Of those chosen for the Oxford trial half will receive the Covid- vaccine, and half will receive a control vaccine that protects against  meningitis  - but not coronavirus. The design of the trial means patients will not know which vaccine they have received, but medics will. Sarah Gilbert, professor of vaccinology at the Jenner Institute, led the pre-trial research and said she was % confident the vaccine would be effective. She said: Personally I have a high degree of confidence in this vaccine. Of course, we have to test it and get data from humans. We have to demonstrate it actually works and stops people getting infected with coronavirus before using the vaccine in the wider population. The vaccine is made from a weakened version of the common cold virus taken from chimpanzees and has been adapted so it cannot grow in humans.  After being injected into the patient, it enters the cells which start to produce coronavirus proteins. This them kick-starts the immune system, prompting it to produce antibodies to activate killer T-cells that destroy the infection. If a patient goes to encounter coronavirus again, the same antibodies and T-cells are triggered to target and stamp out the virus. In the coming months the two groups will be compared to seethe trial has been successful.

title: mirror campaign demands cash bonus
story: NewsNHS frontline heroes put their lives on the line - they need a cash reward nowThe Sunday Mirror wants our brave frontline heroes to get a cash bonus for every day they risk their own lives to battle coronavirus - the same way the armed forces get combat allowanceShareCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical EditorChris McLaughlinAlan Selby:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsCarer June Anderson died after a battle with coronavirus at Aintree Hospital on Wednesday April  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThese are all faces of frontline workers who have selflessly laid down their lives in the battle against Covid-. As the death toll among NHS staff and private care employees soared to  tonight, it brought home the appalling dangers these heroes face daily. And that is why today the Sunday Mirror is launching a campaign for a scheme to be launched to reward them now – the same way in which our brave troops are paid more for risking death in combat. We are calling for a special daily allowance to be paid immediately to nurses, doctors, support staff and care workers who are putting their lives on the line to get us through the coronavirus crisis. Our campaign will be taken up in Parliament on Monday in a Commons motion tabled by senior Labour MP Jon Trickett. He said: “Health workers are our first defence in the fight against this disease. They need better help now.” Mr Trickett, a former Shadow Cabinet minister, said: “Next week is May Day. “What better way to celebrate the new month and the internationally recognised workers’ day than by supporting this excellent initiative by the Sunday Mirror ” And Fire Brigades Union leader Matt Wrack added: “Clapping is great, but clapping is not enough.” Delivering the special supplement would be based on the extra tax-free daily operational allowance given to our Armed Forces in war zones. Acting Liberal Democrat leader Ed Davey said: “I fully support the Sunday Mirror’s campaign to recognise the bravery of ­Britain’s health and care workers. “ The GMB union, which represents more than , workers in the NHS and care sector, also backed us. National Secretary Rehana Azam said: “If we are really serious about valuing these workers they absolutely need a service allowance now.”The calls for more cash came as tributes were paid to two of the latest health heroes to give their lives. Married dad Larni Zuniga, , who was a senior nurse at a care home, died at St Thomas’ Hospital in London, where PM Boris Johnson was treated. Larni, of Godalming, Surrey, was hailed by his NHS theatre nurse cousin Christian as “a true professional who touched the lives of many”.His we Edith said he was now “enjoying Heaven” while daughter Mutya said: “I can’t stop crying. It’s too painful.” Meanwhile it emerged that the most recent victims had included a nurse who had kept bravely working at . Mahadaye Jagroop, who was known as Mary, died at Birmingham’s Heartlands Hospital, where she had cared “relentlessly” for corona patients. Former colleague Thalia Zong wrote in a tribute to her: “The memory of you and your beautul smile, which has always inspired me, will continue to do so through these tough times.”While it is now widely acknowledged that all frontline workers deserve a better deal pay reviews would take time to be introduced. This way those most at risk in caring for corona victims would get extra cash in their pockets now. There is precedent for finding money immediately. When banks faced collapse during the financial crash of October  they got an instant £billion in bailouts.And with , nursing jobs unfilled, frontline medical staff were already overstretched even before the corona crisis began. Our nurses on £. an hour get less than in other countries. In Germany, for example, they get £. an hour. Australia pays nurses £. an hour, Italy £., Norway £. and Sweden £. – almost twice what ours get. Hospital support staff are on pitully poor earnings with porters, healthcare assistants and cleaners getting around just £, a year. Living Wage Foundation director Katherine Chapman said: “Care work is a huge industry with around a million workers supporting some of the most vulnerable people in society, often for incredibly low pay. Now there is a real opportunity to create lasting change in the sector.” Many carers are paid what the Government calls its National Living Wage – the legal minimum for workers aged  and over – of £. an hour.

title: mum lost 4st 10 weeks
story: NewsMum lost st in  weeks after horric condition made her go to toilet  times a dayMum-of-two Trudi Stonard, , from Walsall, West Midlands went from st lb to st lb in just  weeks and was “lucky to survive” after being diagnosed with ulcerative colitisShareCommentsByKatie PearsonLucy Skoulding:,  APR NewsTrudi Stonard, , was ‘lucky to survive’ " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman nearly died after a rare bowel condition made her to go to the toilet more than  times a day - causing her to lose a staggering four stone in  weeks. Trudi Stonard,  from Walsall, West Midlands, was “lucky to survive” after she was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis, a condition which causes inflammation of the colon and rectum. In just  weeks, her condition escalated to “le-threatening” and surgeons spent six hours removing her bowel which was so inflamed it was like “it was on fire”. The mum-of-two started experiencing extreme stomach pain in December . She was even in agony when she ate a packet of crisps.She was misdiagnosed with irritable bowel syndromebut Trudi feared it was more serious when she started passing blood after eating “one bite of KFC”.Trudi dropped from st lb to st lb and her son Leonard, now seven, refused to go near her because she looked “unrecognisable”. She underwent surgery to remove her part of her colon and replace it with a stoma bag at New Cross Hospital, Wolverhampton, in February . Despite the damage to her insides, Trudi managed to “miraculously” fall pregnant with her son Bobby-Jo, now four, and has learnt to embrace her stoma. Trudi said: “In the space of  weeks I went from a normal person, to someone with a stoma bag. “The surgeon met me after my surgery and said he’d never seen a colon that bad. “In fact, it look so inflamed, it he said it looked like it was on ‘fire’. “He said: ‘I just wanted to stamp on it and put it out.’ While I was suffering from colitis, I lost around five stone. I lost so much weight people thought I was anorexic.  Itaposs been a dficult adjustment but Iaposve learnt to love my stoma bag. If someone offered to reverse it tomorrow Iaposd so no - itaposs part of who I am now. In December , Trudi started getting stomach pain and going to the loo more frequently. Things escalated in a matter of weeks until everything she ate was leaving her in agony and was rapidly losing weight. Trudi was diagnosed with IBS but she knew suspected it was more serious after she tucked into a takeaway. After ‘one bite’ she rushed to the toilet where she saw blood ‘flowingapos from her behind. Trudi said: “I never had any problems with my stomach until February. “Anything I ate, from a small snack to a meal, was leaving me in agony. Even a packet of crisps caused this crushing pain that felt like I was going to be sick.  “I went to my GP but said it was just IBS and gave me buscopan but nothing helped. “One night I tried to eat some KFC, I had one bite of chicken and I had to dash to the toilet where I saw blood literally flowing from my behind. Trudi went to New Cross Hospital, Wolverhampton, West Midlands, where doctors suspected she had food poisoning and sent home. Two days later she collapsed and her mum Jill Stonard, , rushed her to AE while she was ‘screaming’ in pain. Trudi said: When doctors said it was food poisoning and I thought: ‘That makes sense.’ “I thought that would explain why my stomach had been so bad. But when my mum found me screaming in pain, she took me straight back to hospital. Trudi continued to lose weight and was going to the loo over  times a day. In the space of  weeks she gone from st lb to st lb. She said: I kept losing weight and couldnapost keep anything down. One day I went to the loo around  times in one day.  The doctors tried to take a stool sample but the bed pan looked like someone had poured a pint of blood in it. “I felt awful and was barely able to get out of bed. My brought my little boy up to visit but he wouldnapost go anywhere near me. “He said: ‘You’re not my mummy’. That was devastating. Trudi was sent for more tests over two weeks including a colposcopy – which involved sending a camera through her colon. She said doctors found the lining of bowel ‘covered in ulcers’ and she was finally diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. Doctors tried every medication but nothing was working. In February , Trudiaposs last resort was to undergo surgery called a colostomy.  It involved removing the affected bowel and erting the end through opening in the tummy called a aposstomaapos. The stoma would then be fitted with a stoma bag to collect the waste. She said: “When they did the colposcopy they said my bowel was literally covered in ulcers. We tried every medication and steroid but I was throwing it all up. In the end, it was an operation or Iaposd lose my le. Surgery should only take a couple of hours but my bowel was so bad, it took them six hours. Trudi was told it would be dficult to conceive because of the damage to her insides. She was shocked to discover she had fallen pregnant three months after her op in June . Despite the odds against her, Trudi continued with her pregnancy and found out it was a little boy. “He was a total surprise – I was told it would be impossible to have a baby with condition,apos she said. Things started well but once the bump appeared, it put a lot of pressure of my stoma. I was told that I wouldnapost carry to full term but Bobby-Jo was a little fighter. The real problem was going into labour. I hadnapost been to the loo for ages, Iaposd forgotten how to push! Giving birth was the hardest thing in the world – luckily, he arrived safe and sound.

Mathematician Andrew Jeffrey mocked up his own Ofsted report for the ‘Jeffrey Home School’ based on the kitchen table, near Brighton.Posting the report on Twitter he said: “Despite rumours they were on furlough, we just had an unannounced visit from @Ofstednews.“It didn’t go as badly as we feared. Here’s the summary report.” The Jeffrey Home School received a ‘requires improvement’ rating in all categories including leadership and management, the safety of pupils, the quality of teaching and the achievement of pupils. The report said the headteacher is “eminently qualied” but is “regularly seen wearing nothing but a dressing gowns and underpants”. It adds: “This sets a very poor example to the pupils. Also in the evening, both members of staff are often observed drinking alcohol in front of the pupils.” Other noteworthy comments include pupils late to lessons and leaving class without permission with one Key Stage Two pupil being caught “playing Fortnite and claiming it was a Geography project.” He was excluded for two weeks. Another child was found watching a Netflix boxset without supervision.Luckily the real Ofsted saw the funny side, replying: “Dear Headteacher. Monitoring visit showed excellent leadership skills in dficult circumstances. “Our admiration and thanks to all parents and children keeping it together.” His tweet went viral receiving .k likes from people facing a similar struggle of home schooling. One user: “Great work. But seriously, you’ve been fortunate to avoid a  and questions need to be asked about the role of governors MAT LA.” Andrew replied: “Only because Iaposm a trained inspector so I knew how to avoid a few obvious pitfalls.” Another said: “Thank you, this made me smile.” On Twitter Andrew has been sharing advice to parents about working from home.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailChanging rooms could be closed, hand sanitizer stations installed and social distancing markers laid down in order for shops to reopen, it has been said today. Keen for its members to welcome customers as soon as possible, the British Retail Consortiumhas published a number of measures ahead of a possible easing of lockdown. But at the moment there is no indication of when non-essential businesses will be able to get going again. The retail lobby says shops therefore need to be prepared and has provided advice on how to minimise risks. The BRC has worked with the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers to produce guidance on social distancing for non-food retail stores, drawing on Government advice as well as lessons learned from supermarkets in recent weeks. The recommended measures include limiting entry and exit points, using floor markings to outline social distancing and keeping changing rooms closed. The guidance also suggests installing cleaning stations with hand sanitiser and disinfectant wipes at the front of stores. BRC chief Helen Dickinson said the measures would serve to ensure the safety and wellbeing of both customers and staff. Since the lockdown, many retailers have proved how shops can be run safely and effectively in line with the Governmentaposs social distancing advice, she said.  Continued close collaboration with Government, including public support for the steps retailers are taking and adequate notice to get supply chains up and running, will mean that retail businesses can start trading again slowly and safely, and customers can feel confident that they are safe toto shops.Some stores, including hardware giants Homebase and BQ, have already reopened in the UK with social distancing measures like two-metre floor markers and perspex screens. While McDonaldaposs, which closed all its outlets a month ago, is planning to reopen its drive-thrus and delivery services next month. Other European countries, such as Austria, the Czech Republic and former epicentre Italy, have eased their own measures but also imposed them before the UK.In Austria small shops have started to reopen but customers are required to wear masks, with plans for a gradual lting of restrictions on large businesses and eventually gathering in June.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA man set a dog on his girlfriend on her birthday, leaving her needing more than  stitches and scarred for le. Lucy Jackson-Stanese, , met “charming” Ben Robertson on Tinder - and within a few weeks they were living together.Three months later, he hit her for the first of many times, but Lucy was in denial and stayed with Ben, the Daily Star reports.However, when she used Clareaposs Law - a scheme to let people find out from policetheir partner has a history of domestic violence - a police officer warned her, saying: “Leave now or you will die.” Lucy, a PE and swimming teacher, said: “Ben seemed to be everything I ever wanted. I was smitten and soon afterwards we moved in together. “It was small changes at first. He’d tell me not to wear make-up. Soon, the emotional abuse turned physical. Lucy, from Essex, said: “After one argument the neighbours heard the shouting and saw him being violent to me and rang the police. He had dragged me out of bed naked and put me on the balcony.” On Lucy’s st birthday last July, Ben set a dog on her. She said: “It was a Staffordshire bull terrier he’d brought home to look after.  “We argued as I wanted to go to see my family, and he ordered the dog: ‘Go for her!’ “I needed over  stitches to my face and arm, a blood transfusion and plastic surgery.” Lucy said she still stayed with Ben, until she was told he had abused four other women and had even been sent to prison twice. She said: “The police officer said Ben had locked one woman inside a house and hit another repeatedly with a bottle. But I didn’t want to believe any of it.  “The police officer replied, ‘I’m promising you, Lucy. If you don’t leave him now, you’ll end up dead’.” Lucy pressed charges, with a court hearing fixed for January  – but in December last year Ben took his own le, aged . Lucy is now urging any women who suspect their partner is mistreating them to contact police.  She said: “If you have any doubt whatsoever about the person you’re with, get them checked out under Clare’s Law. It could save your le.” Clareaposs Law allows police to disclose information about a partner’s previous history of domestic violence or violent acts. It was introduced in  after a campaign by Michael Brown, the father of murdered Clare Woods, . The mum of one was strangled and set on fire at her home in Salford, Lancashire, in February  by boyfriend George Appleton.He had a record of violence against women. Michael argued that her death could have been prevented had she known her partner’s history. Theresa May, who was Home Secretary when the law was introduced, said: Domestic abuse shatters lives – Clare’s Law provides people with the information they need to escape an abusive situation before it ends in tragedy.

He credited Britons obeying the lockdown and social distancing measures for the apparent decline in new cases and a plateauing in deaths. However, Professor Powis said the lockdown has begun to pay off but warned cases could soar and there could be a second waveBritons begin become complacent. Speaking at Sundayaposs briefing at Downing Street, he told reporters the benefit of social distancing was beginning to be felt in the stabilisation of the number of new cases. He said: You can see we now have a very definite trend of a reduced number of people in hospitals - that is most marked in London. But there is the beginnings of that in the Midlands and other areas of the UK. That is definitely showing that our compliance with social distancing is proving to be beneficial, it is reducing the transmission and spread of the virus. Professor Powis noted there had been a decline in the number of critical care beds used for Covid- patients. He added: Those benefits have occurred not by luck, but because people have complied with the instructions that we have all been given and they have followed the science. The science of this is quite straight forward,we reduce the number of people that can be infected from an inidual person who has the virus to below on average one, then the virus starts to go into decline and the number of infections starts to fall. The NHS boss said the lockdown efforts have begun to pay off, but warned they would only continue to pay offBritons continue to comply with social distancing measures.   He added: My fear, as the fear of all of us, is that those curves wonapost continue to be on a down trend but will start to go in an upward trend.  We are not at a point where any of us can be absolutely confident that that is not going to be the case - we want to avoid a second peak, we want to avoid a rise. I canapost emphasise enough that this is not the time to say weaposve done a good job. Speaking alongside Professor Powis, Environment Secretary George Eustice said , Covid- tests had been carried out in the UK - including , on Saturday. He told a Downing Street briefing that some , people have tested positive - an increase of , cases since the day before. He added: , people are currently in hospital with the coronavirus in the UK, down from , on April . And sadly, of those hospitalised with the virus, , have now died, and that is an increase of  fatalities since yesterday. We express our deepest condolences to the families and friends of these victims.Asked why the Government did not record coronavirus-related deaths in care homes in the same way it has done for hospitals, Professor Powis said there was a dference in the way data is collected. He said: In the NHS we work with several hundred hospitals to collect that data on a daily basis. We are collecting the data for people who have died in hospital who we know have tested positive. All those organisations are within the NHS family who are used to putting in daily reports to NHS England. The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. In the care home sector, there are many, many thousands of care homes operated by many, many independent organisations, so that sort of daily rhythm of reporting in is just not something that occurs in care homes in the same way. Schools will have to adhere to social distancing measures should they reopen during the pandemic, the Environment Secretary said.Mr Eustice added: Dominic Raab addressed this earlier this morning. And stressed the importance, that even as you start to consider steps such as that , it would still be important in such a setting to have social distancing measures.Asked about tests for care home residents and staff, he said: We have been ramping up capacity to do those test.  It currently stands at over , a day. We have started to invite large numbers of people working in the care sector and care homes to undertake those tests and signicant numbers have. Mr Eustice dismissed media reports that all travellers ing to the UK from abroad will have to be quarantined on arrival for  days as speculation. title: ve day 75 years on
story: NewsV.E Day  years on: The real story of how Britain won the warBritain played a far more dominant and skillful role in the Second World War than we often give ourselves credit, and with a pragmatic ruthlessness that is rarely appreciatedShareCommentsByAl MurrayJames Holland:,  APR NewsBritain played a far more dominant and skillful role in the Second World War than often credited " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThere is a persistent myth about Britain’s part in the Second World War that goes something like this: at Dunkirk, the Army was saved by the skin of its teeth and not least by plucky civilians hurrying across the Channel in their Little Boats. With our backs to the walls, the Few – the Spitfire and Hurricane pilots of the RAF – then kept the mighty Luftwaffe at bay, Blitz spirit kept us going through the dark days of enemy bombing and, although we stood alone, David held back Goliath until the Americans finally joined in with their enormous material might. It was all a bit amateurish and Captain Mainwaring, but we stuck it out to the bitter end, although we’ve been paying for it pretty much ever since. Lend lease repayments finished only during Gordon Brown’s time as Prime Minister. It might surprise a few to know that almost every bit of what is written above is wrong. Rather, we British played a far more dominant and skillful role in the war than we often give ourselves credit and with a pragmatic ruthlessness that is rarely appreciated. Anniversaries are useful because they give us time to pause and reflect, and in this th anniversary year it’s no bad thing to look afresh at Britain’s really very impressive part in the eventual victories of . For the next three days, we are going to be offering a brief outline of Britain’s war, and today will be looking at the opening year up to the end of the Battle of Britain. It’s worth pointing out that no matter how diminished we might have become since, on September , , when PM Neville Chamberlain announced war with Germany, Britain was the biggest global superpower. We had the largest empire the world has ever known, and even greater extra-imperial assets. Britain owned huge stakes in Argentina, for example, with many farms, ports and railways run by British firms. London was also the centre of the greatest global trading network ever witnessed. We had the world’s largest navy, largest merchant navy – some , ships – and access to around % of the world’s merchant fleet.These were huge assets. Germany had almost no merchant marine, a very small navy and was virtually land-locked within Europe because the moment war was declared, the Royal Navy imposed a very tight naval blockade.  The shortage of supplies, and especially food and oil, dominated Germany’s war strategy from the outset.  Britain had a small army because we had a very large navy and rapidly growing RAF, and because its ally France had a massive army that was better equipped than any other in the world, including that of Germany. The trouble was, France was politically fractured with a coalition government of many parties and was unable to ever agree anything themselves, let alone much with their British ally. The lack of political direction had, in turn, a deep effect on the military leadership. So, it was not until April  that Britain and France finally agreed to mine the shipping routes in northern Norway to stop Swedish iron ore reaching Germany.  By that time, Germany had decided to invade Norway and Denmark and did so with clinical efficiency. After all, their lines of supply were much shorter and most of Britain’s army was in France awaiting a German attack there.  Denmark was conquered in a day. Norway took until June, but although the British and small French contingency were beaten on land, the Royal Navy hammered the German Kriegsmarine, whose surface fleet was half destroyed and which never recovered. Then, on May , the Germans attacked in the west, pouring into France and the Low Countries with two massive thrusts. That same day, Winston Churchill became Prime Minister after Chamberlain resigned over Norway, so Britain was politically in crisis at the very moment the biggest clash of the war to date was beginning. Britain had sent  isions to France, compared with  French and  Belgian, so their contribution was very small. Nonetheless, Britain had the world’s first fully mechanised army.  In contrast, of the  isions the Germans used, only  were mechanised. The other  used what armies always had – horses and their soldiers’ own two feet. Only % of the German Army was fully trained. But those  German mechanised isions did for the French. France had plenty of tanks, guns and soldiers, but very few radios and, with telephone lines cut and refugees clogging roads, its commanders struggled to communicate with one another.  But the Germans had plenty of radios and their infantry, artillery and tanks were able to co-ordinate attacks, while above, the Luftwaffe marauded freely because the French had no air defence system. This meant the Germans were able to pick off the superior numbers of French in penny packets. And when the French and Belgians started to fall back, the British Expeditionary Force had to do the same and ended up at Dunkirk.  When they had fought, the British had fought very well and effectively. Their counter-attack at Arras on May , , gave the Germans a real scare. It was the Royal Navy and the RAF – along with the superb defence of the Dunkirk perimeter – that ensured the bulk of the British Army got back home.Little Ships accounted for perhaps % of those lted and most were taken not from the beaches but from the East Mole – a wooden pier that extended from the harbour and which was untouched by bombs.  The RAF of Fighter Command shot down large numbers of Stuka e-bombers and so it could be argued that the Battle of Britain began then. At any rate, once France fell in the third week of June , Britain was far from alone. The Dominions and Empire backed Britain, while the world’s resources were readily accessible. Although U-boats started making a menace of themselves, there were never more than  operating at one time in the Atlantic – and that was not enough to bring Britain to her knees.  We also had the world’s first fully co-ordinated air defence system, the entire Home Fleet ready and waiting to intercept any invasion attempt, and also “Harry Tate’s Navy” – the Royal Navy Patrol Service – which were fishing boats and crews converted to minelayers and sweepers, armed and also acting as an anti-invasion watch. There was also the Home Guard – more than two million strong by August , and not all Dad’s Army by any means. Nor was Britain defended only by the Few in Fighter Command.  Coastal and Bomber Commands were attacking enemy targets every day, including four raids on Berlin before the first deliberate Luftwaffe raid on London on September .Aircraft production was more than double that of Germany in , intelligence was vastly superior and the Luftwaffe were hammered in the battle. The Spitfires and Hurricanes were not the last line of defence, but the first, and nor were they always outnumbered.  On Sunday, September , , what became known as Battle of Britain Day,  enemy aircraft attacked London in the largest raid of the day, but were attacked in turn by  Spitfires and Hurricanes. Germany had planned to fight a short, sharp war, but failure to defeat Britain in  meant it needed resources from where, and realistically, they could only come from the Soviet Union.

story: NewsCoronavirus: Couple slammed over newborns name which hospital staff thought was jokeThe parents have faced criticism from hospital workers who thought the name was a joke and said it is disrespectful to those who have died from coronavirus Covid- during the pandemicShareCommentsByNatalia PenzaGrace Witherden:,  APR NewsThe name has raised eyebrows" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email An Argentinian couple have been accused of showing a “total lack of respect” after using coronavirus as inspiration for their baby’s name.Parents Eduardo Sequeira and Debora Maidana gave their baby a middle name of ‘Covid’ and said it would mean he grows up a “strong little man”. He was born in Ceres Hospital, around  miles northwest of the city of Santa Fe in central-eastern Argentina on Wednesday. The move has upset workers at the Ceres Hospital, who originally thought it was a joke. One worker told local paper El Litoral: “I’m saddened this has happened, especially at our hospital. “I think it’s a total lack of respect for the people who have died from this virus. “At first I thought it was a joke but when I saw it had been certied by the hospital I realised it was true. “It’s pretty off. Sadly this is going to be world news and the Ceres Hospital stamp is going to be on it.” But hospital director Silvana Torres said the name was the parents’ decision and not something she was questioning. The baby’s grandmother Alicia Jauregui said the name came out of a conversation between his parents saying their child was going to be famous because he arrived at a dficult time and that was going to make him a “strong little man.” The baby was born by C-section weighing just over lbs. Alicia told a local journalist: “I’m so happy, he’s my th grandchild. “It was beautul to see him for the first time. He’s just like his dad when he was born.” The killer virus also inspired a couple in India who gave birth to twins. The children were named Covid and Corona and were born at a hospital in Raipur on March .

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn Israeli professor has claimed that coronavirus will disappear after  days – with or without intervention. The unproven claims were made by Professor Isaac Ben-Israel, who is the head of the security studies programme at Tel Aviv University. He said that all efforts to stop the spread will lead to the same result because the virus is “self-limiting”, and peaks at  days before rapidly declining. His calculations claim to show the pattern of daily new infections as a percentage of accumulated number of infections. They start at around  per cent, but decrease to  per cent after six weeks, and ultimately reached a level of less than five per cent a week later. In his own article he wrote: “Our analysis shows that this is a constant pattern across countries. Surprisingly, this pattern is common to countries that have taken a severe lockdown, including the paralysis of the economy, as well as to countries that implemented a far more lenient policy and have continued in ordinary le. However no countries have implemented exactly the same social distancing measures against the virus so it is dficult to compare them. There is also no country which can used as a baseline.For example, even though Sweden has imposed the fewest restrictions it has still implemented some measures against the virus. When The Times of Israel asked him how the virus would die without any intervention, he said: I have no explanation. There are all kinds of speculations. Maybe it’s related to climate, or the virus has a le-span of its own. In a television debate on Monday, Professor Gabi Barbash, a hospital director and the former Health Ministry director general, said that death tolls would have been far higherIsrael and other countries had not taken the steps against the virus.  The Daily aposs own analysis across  countries found the peak appeared to be closer to  days instead of . In response to the claims, Professor Babak Javid, a consultant in infectious diseases at Cambridge University Hospitals told the publication: To suggest that mitigation measures are irrelevant to the trajectory of the spread of the virus doesnapost take into account the fundamental concept of the dynamics of transmission of an infectious disease within infectious, susceptible and immune iniduals in a population.” He saidexponential growth is unchecked it will decline but that is only the casea majority of the population are infected. He added: “It is not truemitigation efforts have reduced the base number of people infected.”  Britain’s Chief Medical Officer Chris Witty said the only “exit” from lockdown will be a vaccine. He said: “In the long run, the exit from this is going to one be one of two things... One of which is a highly effective vaccine. And or highly effective drugs so that people stop dying of this disease eventhey catch it, or which can prevent this disease in vulnerable people.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThirty four years ago Chernobylaposs fourth reactor exploded, spewing deadly radiation around the world in the deadliest nuclear explosion the world has ever seen. The disaster is directly responsible for  people but many hundreds,not thousands, more became seriously ill and lost their lives in the aftermath. The explosion was caused by what should have been a routine test - but its impact was immediate and the aftermath has stretched over the following decades. The  disaster saw huge plumes of radiative smoke threaten to cover the whole of Europe and beyond. The impact of those coming into direct contact with the radiation was instant and horric. People living in Pripyat were initially kept in the dark about what had happened - but when they started falling ill with severe headaches, vomiting and uncontrollable fits of coughing, the authorities finally took action. A day after the explosion the first buses arrived to get people to safety. Lives are still being lost due to the devastating effects of that day on April , . Dozens of heroic men and women sacriced their own lives in a desperate bid to make the ruin reactor safe and put out the flames following the explosion. Tonne up tonne of sand was dumped on the structure and courageous staff worked around the clock to make the site as safe as possible. Coal miners were drafted in from across the Soviet Union to dig under the reactoraposs core to creat a huge pool of liquid nitrogen to cool the nuclear fuel within. Finally, when the fires were out of the radiative contained as well as it could be, a huge concrete structure was built over the site. It took  days to build the first sarcophagus, using , cubic metres of concrete and , tonnes of metal framework. Yaroslav Melnik, the leader of a group of firefighters brought in from the town of Ivano Frankivsk, remembered: “We worked in three shts, but only for five to seven minutes at a time because of the danger. “After finishing, weaposd throw our clothes in the garbage.” Later named the aposliquidatorsapos, thousands of these men and women are reported to have died during their work, or suffered long-term illnesses from acute radiation exposure. It had been hoped it would contain the deadly radiation leaking from the nuclear plant - but dangerous levels were still escaping every day. And this huge structure was only designed to be temporary -  years after the explosion, things had become critical once again. Now, after the best minds in the world came up with a solution a huge steel sarcophagus covers the ruined reactor, which itaposs hoped will keep it safe for decades to come. However, the surrounding area is still unihabitable, with those who had called Pripyat their home before the disaster now relocated. It was  hours after the disaster before the evacuation started and many of those who were livng in Pripyat have suffered devastating consequences. Whataposs left behind is an eerie and abandoned ghost town with chillig reminders of the ordinary, family le that one existed there the only things left behind. TVs stand unwatched, cots lie empty and kitchens and living rooms that were once filled with love and laughter are now silent and have been reclaimed by nature. Classrooms where pupils used to sit at the rows of desks are covered in cobweb and dust as sunlight streams in through the broken windows. Pripyat had been a busy and bustling town, built in the shadow of the Chernobyl nuclear power station. With work for thousands of people it was prosperous and fairgrounds, shopping malls, restaurants and bars all sprung up to provide those living there with entertainment. These now lie abandoned with trees, vines and creepers sprawling across rollercoasters. Apartment blocks are now scarred by the weather after remaining unlived in for the last  years. Photojournalist and tourist guide Anton Petrus has visited Pripyat several times in recent years. He said: Pripyat is the worst place Iaposve ever been. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email While his fellow countrymen and women lived in extreme poverty or starved to death, a young Kim Jong-un lived a spoilt le in the lap of luxury.It is said that his father, Kim Jong-il, gave him his first car when he was just seven years old and he was raised to believe he was a demigod. His parents showered him with gts and toys while normal North Korean children had nothing, adult servants were forced to tend to his every need, and he was shipped off to an exclusive school in Switzerland to study. Very little changed when he became an adult and later succeeded his father in , and now there are unveried claims that the dictatoraposs reign has come to an end. Speculation over Kimaposs health has been re since he missed a celebration of the birthday of his late grandfather - North Koreaaposs founder Kim Il-sung - on April .Seoul-based website DailyNK, run mostly by North Korean defectors, then reported that Kim had undergone heart surgery, citing an unnamed source inside the country.Since then, reports about Kimaposs health have ied widely and each one is incredibly dficult to very given North Koreaaposs secrecy and isolation. There have been claims that Kim is dead, in a vegetative state or coma, is gravely ill, or is stable and recovering at a countryside villa. The Hong Kong TV network HKSTV has claimed he has died, according to a very solid source, while a Japanese magazine reports that he is in a vegetative state after undergoing heart surgery. It was also revealed yesterday that China, the countryaposs chief ally, deployed medics to North Korea to advise on the ruler.Three anonymous sources told Reuters that a team of doctors and officials left Beijing on Thursday, although the agency was unable to very what the mission signals in terms of Kimaposs health.North Korea is one of the world’s most secretive countries, and the health of its leaders is a matter of state security.  According to The Great Successor, a book chronicling Kimaposs le by Washington Post journalist Anna Field, his every move is calculated to ensure he stays in power. Under his rule, the country carried out its first successful hydrogen bomb test in , and has developed a new generation of cyber hackers. Field believes that Kim is very consciously trying to look like his grandfather, who is still revered in North Korea. Kimaposs ruthlessness has not seen members of his immediate family spared.  Half-brother Kim Jong-nam died after being attacked with a nerve agent at Kuala Lumpar International Airport in Malasia in . While his death is regarded officially as an assassination, it is thought of by many as a public execution. Although it has never been proved, Kim is believed to have ordered the killing, believing his half-brother was a threat. Four North Korean suspects left the airport shortly after the assassination and left Korea without being arrested.  And his uncle Jang Song Thaek - described in North Korean media as despicable human scum, worse than a dog - was reportedly fed to  hungry dogs in . As a child, the gardens of his home were filled with cages containing monkeys and bears for his entertainment. Huge playrooms boasted more toys than any European store and the gardens inside the walled compounds where he was raised were so large that many called theme parks. A personal chef was hired to be the future North Korean dictatoraposs friend - and the young Kim would don military gear to boss adults around. Contact with other children was scarce, Field writes, with his eighth birthday party attended by high-ranking adults instead of other children. Even when North Koreans were plunged into famine, Kim was probably unaware of the horric conditions they were enduring, she believes.In an interview with Vox, Field said: He was brought up to believe that he was a demigod from the age of three or four, probably as long as he can remember. The author said he was close to his mother, Ko Yong Hui, from who he got the belief that he was a military genius, as well as a love of basketball. Her influence was seen everywhere from the cartoons of her that suddenly started appearing on TV to the way her sons were promoted and moved up the ranks, Field says. In the s Kim was sent to live and study at the International School of Bern in Switzerland under a  identity. This was done in the hope that exposure to the West would turn him into a reformer - but the author said the opposite was true.

story: NewsTop US senator says he would be shockedKim Jong-un is not dead or incapacitatedThe North Korean leader has not been seen publicly in over two weeks. He reportedly underwent heart surgery earlier this month and reports said he could be gravely ill, incapacitated or even deadShareCommentsByChiara Fiorillo:,  APR NewsSenator Lindsey Graham said he believes Kim Jong-un is dead or incapacitated " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA top US senator said he would be shockedKim Jong-un is not dead or incapacitated, it has been reported. Lindsey Graham made the comments after rumours that the North Korean leader was in critical condition or dead spread around the world this week. The US senator said yesterday evening that he did not have any direct knowledge about Kimaposs condition, but that the extended silence from North Korea is very telling. The South Carolina Republican told Fox News: Itaposs a closed society. I havenapost heard anything directly, but Iaposll be shockedheaposs not dead or in some incapacitated state because you donapost let rumors like this go forever or go unanswered in a closed society which is really a cult, not a country, called north Korea. So I pretty well believe he is dead or incapacitated. And I hope the long suffering north Korean people will get some reliefhe is dead. Senator Graham added: President Trump is willing to do business with North Korea in a win-win fashion. Sothis guy is dead, I hope the guy who takes over will work with President Trump to make North Korea a better place for everybody.Trump said on Thursday that he believes reports about Kimaposs condition were incorrect, The Washington Examiner reports. The vice director of Hong Kong Satellite TelevisionShijian Xingzou says a very solid source has told her Kim Jong Un is already dead, according to Mail Online.Separately, a Japanese media outlet has claimed Kim is in a vegetative state after he underwent heart surgery earlier in the month. However, images released by  North, a Washington-based project monitoring North Korea, seemed to show what is believed to be Kimaposs train in Wonsan, a port town in the east, on April  and .According to reports, the station is reserved for the sole use of the Kim family. The trainaposs presence does not prove the whereabouts of the North Korean leader or indicate anything about his health but it does lend weight to reports that Kim is staying at an elite area on the countryaposs eastern coast, the  North report said.  On April , a South Korean source told Reuters their intelligence was that Kim was alive and would likely make an appearance soon. The person said he did not have any comment on Kimaposs current condition or any Chinese involvement. The -year-old North Korean leader was already said to be in general poor health condition, being a heavy smoker and morbidly obese - which makes him more susceptible to major health issues.

title: dundee deefiant ross county
story: “It felt like we had won the league” – Dundee finishing sixth in the second tier wouldn’t usually spark frenzied celebration but nine years ago today the class of   cemented themselves in club folklore.‘Deefiant’ status was confirmed with a - win at Ross County on April ,  # a single goal from -year-old Leighton McIntosh causing “an explosion” in the stands, according to the Dundonian.Months after administration had seen the Dark Blues given a huge -point penalty by the league, Barry Smith’s beleaguered side beat the odds by avoiding the drop to the Second Division.The campaign had begun with swingeing cuts across the club’s staff, leaving a skeleton squad to battle against what seemed like the rest of the world.Current Dens youth coach Gary Irvine had not long been signed by Gordon Chisholm from St Johnstone before the club was plunged into a financial crisis.He told the Tele: “The -point penalty came in and it felt like they were kicking us when we were already down.“From our point of view, it felt like they were trying to put the club under with that – I think it is the biggest points penalty ever handed out. We felt very hard done by.“The boys who were kept on were feeling really fortunate because they were still getting paid.“I don’t knowit was the plan from the bosses to pick a team that could compete but we ended up with a really good team with some good youngsters left behind.“There was real quality and we said ‘let’s have a go’.”Despite being left with a threadbare squad, former club skipper Smith had some real talent to choose from that season with a good mix of youth and experience.The older heads included former Scotland internationals Rab Douglas and Neil McCann as well as experienced campaigners like Rhys Weston and Matt Lockwood while the younger ones included future Scotland star Leigh Grfiths, Dens hero Gary Harkins and defender Craig Forsyth among others.Called up from the youth team was also striker McIntosh, who hit a purple patch of goals at a critical point in the season – an equaliser against Stirling Albion followed by a double at Morton # before the Dark Blues went north to Dingwall.The match that clinched their unlikely survival turned out to be his final one of the season, however.McIntosh said: “When the match started I actually felt my hamstring go because of the demand of all the games before Ross County.“I think I actually tore the muscle and it was only about  minutes in. I knew the gaffer could tell something was wrong but, being young and naïve, I played through it.“It got worse and worse but it got to the point where I forgot all about it and then got the goal after half-time.“I was always motivated to chase down long balls and this time the goalkeeper took his time.“I nicked it from him and I don’t think I even considered anything about what to do next, it was natural. It was a great feeling despite the pain in my hamstring.“It was a really nice day up there I remember and the supporters were there in their numbers, it was an electric atmosphere.“I scored right in front of them and it was like an explosion.“There won’t be any other games with that kind of circumstance I don’t think, it was unique.“I remember the celebrations on the pitch – it was like we’d won the league. Everyone was ecstatic and it was just pure relief.“I don’t think I realised at the time how signicant it was. My focus was only on playing well and trying to make it as a first-team player.“It was a massive game looking back.“I still get Dundee fans coming up to me in the street to say they were there.”On the game itself, McIntosh’s then team-mate Irvine admits it was all a bit of a blur looking back.He added: “I remember Leighton’s goal, he was one of the really good young boys who did just as much as the older experienced lads.“It was the only goal of the game and, at the end, it felt like we had won the league. The feeling and the celebrations afterwards for what we achieved were amazing.“I’ve always said nothing comes close to that season. I’ve won three league titles and won Challenge Cups where you get a medal at the end for your hard work – there was no medal at the end of that one but I still class saving Dundee and keeping them in the league as my best achievement.”Irvine went on to spend six years at Dens Park as a player before ing as a coach where he took the U  side before the coronavirus shutdown.McIntosh, meanwhile, has had spells at Montrose, Peterhead, Icelandic side UMF Selfoss, Arbroath and Airdrie before signing for National League side Wrexham.Following the departure of manager Bryan Hughes, the now--year-old joined Lee Clark’s Blyth Spartans on loan until the pandemic hit.Despite his contract in Wales running down this summer, McIntosh is sanguine about his future.He added: “I took the opportunity to go down south and I’ve enjoyed it. It’s very competitive and the full-time setup was a big plus for me, too.“Everything is up in the air right now and I’ll have to wait and see what pre-season brings, whenever it starts.“I am out of contract this summer but I understand the furlough scheme will cover out-of-contract players for a time so I’m not overly concerned.“It is what it is, everyone is in the same boat.”🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months.
